fulltitle: Nvidia GeForce RTX 5090 Review, 1440p & 4K Gaming Benchmarks

comments.text:
Update: Testing Ray Tracing @ 4K with DLSS Q sees the 5090 beat the 4090 by a 26% margin on average. This data will be added to the upcoming RTX 5080 review, along with some GeForce 30 series data points.

So 26% is much higher than the 17% we saw at 1440p, but still very underwhelming and lower than the margin we saw for the mostly raster data.

Error Correction: The Dying Light 2 graph shows a 40% uplift for the 5090 over the 4090, which is correct, but we said it was 25%, its not 25%, its 40%. This doesnt affect any of the data, all the data shown in the graphs is correct.
comments.author: @Hardwareunboxed

comments.text:
@mannyc19 Price to performance doesn't change based on anything production related. It's only a measure of how much performance we as customers get per dollar we are willing to pay. If no one is willing to pay 2k for the 5090, Nvidia will be forced to lower the price, and that would improve the price to performance for customers.
If indeed the node the 5090 is manufactured on is much cheaper now than when they made the 4090 (on the same node?) that just improves Nvidia's _margin_, but they're still free to charge whatever consumers are willing to pay.
Now I'm usually the last person to defend Nvidia for anything. But there are other factors as well. The way they split the PCB into 3 separate PCBs connected to each other in order to be able to implement the cooling solution they ended up with is very likely to have increased manufacturing cost, not to mention the vapor chamber they put on. And there's the cost of all the R&D it took to make it possible. That cooler is an engineering miracle!
All that said, and as I mentioned; I nearly never defend Nvidia. In my opinion the 5090 is a frickin embarrassment for Nvidia when it comes to gaming performance. I don't think they've ever had such a poor generational performance increase before. And that despite them also never before having taken this long between a generation. More than 2 years it took them to achieve a 25-35% performance increase? They should be ashamed! And charging more for it than the previous flagship? They should be doubly ashamed! Sadly they are likely to sell though...

comments.text:
You asked for my feedback?  Well 4 days ago but...
The RTX 5090 at $2k MSRP means it will regularly be selling for 20 to 35% more than that. $2k is already an extremely stupid price to pay - and knowing just enough to be dangerous, it also appears to be price gouging - a practice which NVidia began engaging in with the 2000 series cards. So a giant FU to them for that right there.

I represent close the mean average or just slightly above with my 10GB 3080, 5800X3D and 64GB RAM on a 1440p/60 monitor (actually a 55" TV 1m from my face, playing games in a 1440 window but... details...). My budget for a PC when the 4000 series released was about $1,200 USD - So I got the components listed above $350 for the 3080 (used), same for the MB, and same for the NIB RAM and NIB CPU. Using an ancient case and existing 1kW PSU brought me within budget.

This time around my budget is about $1,500 but there is NOTING interesting to buy. If the 4080 cards start selling used for under $500 I might get one of those or if there's a good deal on a 5070 maybe that <shrug> but I keep asking myself why. With my current setup every game without notable exception, runs just fine at 60FPS on the very highest settings even if I sometimes have to use the dreaded DLSS - which by NO MEANS is a complete or perfect solution (Play "Pal World" with DLSS on - LOL). I'm a retired CG artist slash Uni Professor teaching the same so while more CPU cores sounds interesting I no longer actually benefit from ANY of the CPU offerings after the 5800X3D.  Motherboards are not offering anything new - certainly noting I need as my TaiChi has a 10Gig NIC and game performance is extremely close to the same as the newest models on offer. 

NVidia has focused almost all of their efforts on heavy metal Data Center components for AI & Compute and the result is that gamers have to deal with the sloppy leftovers from those ventures. So that's my feedback...  Maybe I'll wait another product cycle and see how the Intel cards are doing or hope unrealistically that AMD/ATI will release a high end card at pre-gouge prices... beyond that I likely as most others with similar setups, will be reading and watching a lot more than buying or upgrading.

comments.text: Two major changes that Hardware Unboxed missed: the new card has PCI-E 5.0 support, and DP 2.1B. So you can now have a X8 interface to the GPU and a X8 interface to a PCI-E 5.0 m.2 SSD. The DP upgrade allows for so many different monitor configurations than before. Such as running a game windowed at 240 Hz.

comments.text: You should only benchmark GPUs when theyre at 99% utilization. I have a 5090. Practically every single ray tracing test, the 5090 starts getting cpu limited. The 5090 in those settings will be 30% or more faster than the 4090. Saying oh its 14% on 1080p dlss Q ray tracing on games like dying light 2? An open world game with cpu bottlenecks up the A? So dumb

comments.text:
The 5000 series gpu should now be dubbed the "youtuber edition". Because theyre the only ones isolated by any of these real world problems - price, availability, free shipping and exceptional direct product support -- and maybe sponsorship fees.

We only get hyped by feeding us their glowing reviews of these sponsored product and some very mild psa from them - as to not offend their paying sponsors while showing placebo effect of public service to their audience.

So now we not only have fake frames, we get disingenuous hyping of products as well.

Us normal consumers have to contend with hyper inflated prices, very low availability and lack of support when these items break.

Consider this, what would they say if they didnt get any sponsorship or available cards from nvidia to "review" their new cards? We might instead get 15 second psa's of tldr.

comments.text:
You asked for my feedback?  Well 4 days ago but...
The RTX 5090 at $2k MSRP means it will regularly be selling for 20 to 35% more than that. $2k is already an extremely stupid price to pay - and knowing just enough to be dangerous, it also appears to be price gouging - a practice which NVidia began engaging in with the 2000 series cards. So a giant FU to them for that right there.

I represent close the mean average or just slightly above with my 10GB 3080, 5800X3D and 64GB RAM on a 1440p/60 monitor (actually a 55" TV 1m from my face, playing games in a 1440 window but... details...). My budget for a PC when the 4000 series released was about $1,200 USD - So I got the components listed above $350 for the 3080 (used), same for the MB and NIB CPU, and same for the NIB RAM. Using an ancient case and existing 1kW PSU brought me within budget.

This time around my budget is about $1,500 but there is NOTING interesting to buy. If the 4080 cards start selling used for under $500 I might get one of those or if there's a good deal on a 5070 maybe that <shrug> but I keep asking myself why. With my current setup every game without notable exception, runs just fine at 60FPS on the very highest settings even if I sometimes have to use the dreaded DLSS - which by NO MEANS is a complete or perfect solution (Play "Pal World" with DLSS on - LOL). I'm a retired CG artist slash Uni Professor teaching the same so while more CPU cores sounds interesting I no longer actually benefit from ANY of the CPU offerings after the 5800X3D.  Motherboards are not offering anything new - certainly noting I need as my TaiChi has a 10Gig NIC and game performance is extremely close to the same as the newest models on offer. 

NVidia has focused almost all of their efforts on heavy metal Data Center components for AI & Compute and the result is that gamers have to deal with the sloppy leftovers from those ventures. So that's my feedback...  Maybe I'll wait another product cycle and see how the Intel cards are doing or hope unrealistically that AMD/ATI will release a high end card at pre-gouge prices... beyond that I likely as most others with similar setups, will be reading and watching a lot more than buying or upgrading.  

:face-fuchsia-poop-shape:

comments.text: To me, the RTX 5090 is just a 4090-Super-Duper. They got the extra performance by giving it more power and a bigger price tag. No improvement in performance-per-dollar or performance-per-watt is just not impressive to me. The only impressive thing here is that they got this MEGALODON GPU into a 2-slot card without issues. The 5080 looks decent but if its going to be faster than the 4080-Super than the 16GB of VRAM might be a little bit low. The 5070-Ti is the card that makes sense to me this generation. It should offer 4080-Super Performance for $250 less and thats just a win. The 5070 12GB once again doesn't have enough VRAM so Ill probably recommend that people looking at a card near $500 - go check out AMD 9070/XT instead. So ya, 5090 for 1% club, 5070-Ti for most gaming Enthusiasts, and AMD for lower budget. Seems like a pretty open-and-shut case.

comments.text: I can't say I'm actually all that excited to spend 2k on a card again period.  I've done it twice, yes each time it was offset by selling my last gpu and this time it would do something similar but I'm not exactly unhappy with the performance of my 4090 and I've had less time to spend gaming as real life trumps all.  I don't play at 4k.  I play at standard 2k ultrawide monitor settings so really I don't need this.  I can't see needing this sort of power unless I upgraded my monitor to one of those superwide effectively dual 4k monitors.  Maybe I'll actually step down a couple of tiers like I've been considering for some period of time instead sometime in the future. I just don't know what Nvidia is aiming for by shipping a card like this at a price that pushes away perhaps ex enthusiasts (because the cost has just gone crazy) like myself when honestly?  You're just getting to see higher numbers at the corner of your monitor that you may or may not be able to truly tell without it.  This frame generation tech only devalues frames more.  Yes, I know it's fake frames but it's highly dependent on what type of game you're playing and what you're hoping to get out of more frames.  The average Joe won't know the difference and will truly swallow what nvidia says about what dlss does for them.  The only people I see this as a need being the fps focused super competitive category.  Also?  It looks like AMD has something similar to dlss 4.0 in the pipeline at very likely less cost.  Is going green that important?  Was this the time to keep that cost?  I'd have argued a return to semi sanity would have been better buuut the market will show the results.  Could be I'm totally wrong.

comments.text: Simple start calling "frame generation" what it actually is... It's an old technology call frame interpolation, the only thing Nvidia did was use an AI model to generate the frames... It takes two frames delays the 2nd and fills in the data between the two frames. Thats why you get the flashing with DLSS you're seeing the fake frame then the 2nd actual frame... You won't see increases in latency BECAUSE ITS THE SAME TWO FRAMES... Old tech made new again and rebranded by Nvidia, again... It's annoying that reviewers keep letting them get away with this...

comments.text:
2000 series had a poor value due to increase in price to justify ray tracing
3000 series had a horrendous price due to chip shortage
4000 series had a poor price due to greed
5000 series has a poor price x perf because it barely moves the needle and doesn't significantly reduce the price on the lower tier cards to compete with actual current prices.

The last actually good family (enphasis on family, not only a single card on the gen) of cards was the 1000 series which is ironically also the last one where we had a focus on raster performance. What people fail to understand is that the RT and tensor cores take up a LOT of space in die and we pay for it both in price but also in raster perf. If we didn't have them, the performance increase in raster in each and everyone of these gens would be significantly higher.

Not saying they shouldn't exist, just that they come at a price and most people seem to ignore that.

comments.text:
Is this  a sign of the end of spectacular improvements in both CPUs and GPUs as Moore's law is close to, if not at the its end?
The 5090 may look to be a sign of diminishing returns for both CPUs and GPUs as to increase processing power, larger chips with higher power consumption may be the only way to increase processing power as the limits of chip miniaturisation and manufacture has been reached . Hence larger chip size, +30% more cores,  +30% more power consumption, +30% processing power, and hence +30% increase in price. This may be why Nvidia are pushing their AI and frame generation so hard.

A solution of significantly faster GPUs may be not in graphics cards, but in some kind of GPU motherboard or integration with a CPU-GPU integrated motherboard or chip where some integrated cooling system is needed.

And sadly, this may be something that makes high end computers out of reach of ordinary consumers. Like the 5090. $4k+ AUD for one of these, and $2K+ AUD for a 5080.  Not value for that kind of money outside the US and Europe where low valued currencies make such cards even more unobtainable, even if there are not going to be shortages of such cards and are abundant in all stores.

comments.text:
I don't think it's fair to directly compare the performance/value uplift of the 5090 vs the 4090 against the 4090 vs 3090.
The 3090 was barely faster than the 3080 Ti, and only about 10-15% faster than the 3080 which had less than half the MSRP. The 3090 should not have been branded as a 90-class GPU and should not have cost $1500. It's not the 5090 that sucks, it's the 3090.
The 5090 isn't amazing by any means, but it's not as bad as the comparison against the 4090 vs 3090 implies. For a comparison similar to the 3090 vs the 4090 which is actually valid, we could consider the 980 Ti vs the 1080 Ti. The 980 Ti didn't suck, yet the 1080 Ti still managed to be about 65% faster for only $50 more - so getting that much genuine performance uplift in a generation can happen, but when it does it's a rare exception. The 5090 is better than the 2080 Ti, at least (which was only 31% faster than the 1080 Ti, but 55-85% more expensive).

comments.text:
I'm glad you do in-depth visual analysis of these upscaling and interpolation technologies rather than giving them a blank check.

Just an additional datapoint on that note though, I buy expensive GPUs (I do productivity stuff on them too) and would rather play at a consistent 30 fps rather than turn on upscaling (or any temporal technology), because they produce unacceptably distracting visual artifacts. Even a small amount of blur or dithering or noise or warping is noticeable and detracts from the experience of the game for me. Granted, I would certainly expect more performance for the price of the card, but I cant accept upscaling as a way to get there - I would rather reduce graphical quality from 'ultra' and/or disable RT to boost fps since while it might look worse in a screenshot, its much nicer in motion.

comments.text:
Kena 50s 3060, 3070 80s 1440p

F1 60s 3060, 3070 100 1440p

New world 1440p 3060 70s, 3070 100

Flight sim 1440p, 3060 40s, 3070 60s

Forza 3070 4k 100,3080 130 on average

Hitman 3070 60s 4k, 3080 80s

4060 4K tsunama at 25 fps, 4070 40s no DLSS

Elden Ring no DLSS 1440p, 4060 40 fps, 4070 70


4080 Forza 4080 110 fps, 4080 140 4K

Avatar 4k 50fps 4080, 4090 70

Hogwarts 4080 4k 45s, 60 4090

As you guys can see, I compared models directly under a higher class, as that's the only way it makes a higher class worth it since the jump will be bigger, which is why it makes no sense to compare a 4090 to a 5090 only 1 gen apart. It only makes sense to compare the 4080 to the 5090, which will skip the 4080s; this way it shows a good jump. The same goes for coming from a card like mine, 4070, to the 5080 or 4060 to 5070.

comments.text:
I'd like to see more latency testing. Like frame gen increase latency. But not having Reflex increases latency even more than frame gen plus reflex. 

Daniel Owen tested Frame Gen in Cyberpunk with dlss 3.

Frame Gen with Reflex was like 45ms

No Frame Gen with Reflex was 35ms

No Frame Gen and No Reflex was 70ms

That was the old cnn model with a base frame rate of 60fps. 

So while i think complaints about the latency of frame gen are justified. We should also be hammering in how not having Nvidia Reflex causes an even higher increase to latency.

comments.text:
"I haven't mentioned MFG until now and that may seem a little bit odd..." Not on Youtube, no :P 

What do I think of the 4090? Given the constraints of dealing with the same 4nm design? Eh, they did what they could. Looking at generational uplift it only really seems to see real uplift when the compression from the process change is present. Otherwise, you're just not going to see a massive uplift. I think overtime as games are optimized yeah it'll probably go from 27% to 35%-40% better. 

Marketing? Eh, they're marketing to their most likely end users who will use the frame generation and all the features at some point if not at any time it's available. "Real" competitive gamers won't use framegen, true enough, but the "average" competitive gamer will, because they just don't know it's on by default. You market to the majority not the minority, so I'm fine with it.

Price? We're really talking value on the Ferrari of video cards? I've long stated video cards are like cars, some people are content with getting from A to B, some need to get their faster. And just like in cars you have your used ones which will get you there and be pretty cheap but not do it very quickly, you've got your older models, your newer models, and then you have the true luxury models, and that's the 5090. And just like that Ferrari (or insert your favorite luxury item here) you're not buying it based on value.
(Edit: for the record I'm a Kia man, so I will not now or ever be buying a 90 series card) 

Ultimately you can spend very little and play any game out there you want, you just have to pay the FPS tax. So the value is subjective and completely based on what pace you can deal with. Ultimately it's what the market can bare, and on a 90 series card? It's proven it'll bare a lot more than two thousand.
comments.author: @David-yx3bd

comments.text:
All NVIDIA had to do was launch the 5090 at the same price as the 4090, and the performance uplifts would have been more favorable. Still nothing to wet your whistle on, because 20-30% gen over gen is what we've come to expect (until the 4090, that is), but a hell of a lot better for 1% or less per $1, and even worse that it does worse than the 4090 in some benchmarks. Again, this kind of data is unlikely to swing anybody already keen to buy a 5090, and also unlikely to convince anyone on the fence to go through with it, but they could have positioned themselves much more favorably. We all know their primary profit margin comes from the datacenter, they could easily have kept it at the same price and not even blinked.

I had conservative estimates of increased average performance in my spreadsheets, and even they were disappointed by the results of the 5090. I genuinely hope the 4090 is not the last GPU we'll see significant performance upgrades from, but I worry with NVIDIA's focus on AI that it will be.

comments.text: Historically high core counts and memory bandwidth scale better with resolution or datasets that can scale with more parallel and sequential workloads. It may be better at traditional rendering like path tracing in Blender/Max/Maya and positioned better for rendering 8k scenes in professional workloads. I would be interested how it works in scientific computing, though I have heard that the emphasis is on 16, 8, and even 4 bit integer instead of the 32 and 64 bit floating point has lead to only modest improvements for scientific applications. If that's true, then the AI market has claimed another victim.

comments.text:
Cost per frame graph with actual current pricing once again shows us why people buy AMD. They are the entire top 4. And that includes the RT results! In raster or with only minimal (mandatory) RT enabled, the entire top 5 would be AMD, most likely. 

I personally don't care about RT and I either disable it or play with the minimum required RT. Raster still looks great, I prefer high FPS (capped at 140), and RT ultimately doesn't make gaming more pleasurable for me (while high FPS does). Gameplay is king, graphics is just a bonus. I'm convinced the vast majority of people actually feel similar to me, but holy cow the FOMO marketing from Nvidia about RT and DLSS is extremely effective. Most Nvidia owners I personally know (not terminally online redditors) actually play with mild RT or disabled RT as well. Nvidia was simply their default purchase due to their name. 

In fact, 90% of people won't know what GPU they have if you akk them. 

I'll do you one better: I bet 80% of gamers would call tech support or even RMA their prebult desktop if you flip their PSU switch off at the back as a prank. Hilarious, but it also tells you most people don't care enough to dig into details and probably don't really care about Ray Tracing. In fact, 80% of gamers probably don't know what Ray Tracing is. 

Internet echo chambers (/cough Reddit) make it look like all gamers are PC enthusiasts who min-max their graphical settings, edit videos and do some some mysterious "AI stuff" on the side. Oh, and CUDA. They need CUDA. Imagine a gamer not having access to CUDA!!

comments.text:
Kena 50s 3060, 3070 80s 1440p

F1 60s 3060, 3070 100 1440p

New world 1440p 3060 70s, 3070 100

Flight sim 1440p, 3060 40s, 3070 60s

Forza 3070 4k 100,3080 130 on average

Hitman 3070 60s 4k, 3080 80s

4060 4K tsunama at 25 fps, 4070 40s no DLSS

Elden Ring no DLSS 1440p, 4060 40 fps, 4070 70


4080 Forza 4080 110 fps, 4080 140 4K

Avatar 4k 50fps 4080, 4090 70

Hogwarts 4080 4k 45s, 60 4090

As you guys can see, I compared models directly under a higher class, as that's the only way it makes a higher class worth it since the jump will be bigger, which is why it makes no sense to compare a 4090 to a 5090 only 1 gen apart. It only makes sense to compare the 4080 to the 5090, which will skip the 4080s; this way it shows a good jump. The same goes for coming from a card like mine, 4070, to the 5080 or 4060 to 5070.

comments.text: I feel like all this AI upscaling and interpolation stuff could be used in much better ways.  For instance, they could isolate dynamic foreground objects in the scene and render them at full resolution and high frame rate.  And then the more static background elements would be rendered at low resolution and frame rate and then get upscaled and composited with the foreground stuff.  That should give you a big performance boost while keeping good fidelity and low latency for the actual important action, basically the best of both worlds. And that's just the most obvious idea that occurred to me, surely the experts should be able to design more sophisticated systems...

comments.text:
The main issue is not that its 25% more expensive (if we stick to MSRP  - as in my country the 4090 is often sold for $3000-3500 USD still) - rather the fact Nvidia is clearly selling this 25% more when it supposed to "replace" 4090. But whats happening is that there is 4090 and you can buy 5090. 

If we stick to mobile phone analogy: The Galaxy S 24 cost x amount of money, then currently costs x - 30% so that the new S25 can cost the exact same as S24 used to cost a year ago. The reason for this because Samsung wants to make sure the 2 are not cannabalizing each other. Obviously with GPUs its slightly different but this 25% performance boost would have been a real game changer if Nvidia sold it for 1600 USD as the 4090 and reduced the amount of 4090 by a few hundred bucks. Because if you sell your "old stuff" as a competition then technically you are running several generation of products. But I guess its still profitable. I guess I'll get my 5090 once I visit states so I can buy it for "more normal" price :D

comments.text:
The TRUE benefit of higher frame rates is the improvement to motion portrayal (smoothness, eye tracking clarity, lesser stepping on relative motions).
Lower end to end latency is the nice bonus side effect.

comments.text: People buy exotic cars, handbags with a fancy name, so price is "meaningless" to that group of deep pocket buyers.  My main concern is the power connector, which I have zero trust in.  I do not do any video-sound editing, nor does anything I've played over the last 16 years or so enable RT.  I do use a Hisense 4K TV (55U8G) which does a decent job of upscaling YouTubes' pathetic bit rate.  What performance is "good enough"?  16g of Vram for a start.  AMD offers several options around $500.  So for the price of a 5090 alone, you could build a 9800X3D PC with a $500-600 GPU and easily get "good enough" gaming performance.  My PC is a glorified game console, if you actually use yours for income, sure, a 5090 purchase could be excused.

comments.text:
The NVIDIA 4000-series GPUs, such as the RTX 4090 and 4080, are built on TSMC's 4N process, a custom variant of their 4nm node specifically optimized for NVIDIA. This is different from the standard 4nm process (used for other applications) and also from the newer 4NP process, which is reportedly being used for the RTX 5000-series.

To clarify:

    4N (used for 4000-series): Customized for NVIDIA with optimizations for power efficiency and transistor performance.
    4NP (used for 5000-series): An enhanced iteration of the 4N process, with further improvements in density and efficiency.

Source: ChatGPT

comments.text:
How res scaling/frame gen should work.
5080 gets 120fps at 1440p native.  You can enable res scaling and frame gen, but choose not to because of the degraded experience and you are already getting the high quality experience you paid for.
4080 gets 90 fps at 1440p native but you can enable res scaling to increase that to 120 if you're OK with lower image quality and image stability.
3080 gets 60 fps at 1440p native but you can enable res scaling and single FG to increase that to 120 if you're OK with lower image quality, lower image stability and higher latency.
2080 needs res scaling to obtain 60fps 1440p but you can enable multi FG to increase that to 120 if you're OK with much lower image quality, much lower image stability and higher latency.

comments.text:
You are being short sighted and are not seeing the trees for the wood.

A 30% uplift is a 30% uplift. At the high end users are more than happy to pay more for that. You can pout and make sarcastic immature comments about "Ti" for the benefit of the mouthbreathers all you want, but the fact remains the card is a big improvement over the previous generation card and people will buy it for that reason. An objective reviewer would point that out instead of transparent attempts to court the glass half empty crowd.

The  other point you are missing is that the card has dramatically improved NP capabilities. Why is this important for gaming? Because previously games could not access the NP cores, but this has now changed, which means that FUTURE game engines will be able to use these cores to improve randering performance. Sure, existing games don't, but that is going to change in the coming years. Games in a year or two are going to have much better uplifts in the 5000 series compared to 4000 cards as a result.

Lastly, video handling has improved, which will benefit content creators. Especially when it comes to 10 bit HEVC 4:2:2 decoding, which previously you needed an Intel CPU to do natively without having to resort to proxies. This will apply to all of the 5000 series btw, not just the 5090.

comments.author: @gariknevskoy8239

comments.text:
@gariknevskoy8239 Nope, you are wrong. The 80 class card was historically on the 102 die, just a bit cut down. Them being on the 103 die also serves to show how Nvidia has been downgrading every single card class to sell less for more. Another piece of evidence is memory BUS interfaces: 128bit was reserved for 50 class cards, 192 bit for 60 class (with very few exceptions in which they were granted 256bit), 256 bit for 70 class, 384 bit for 80 and Titan class cards.
Steve also made a video about exactly a while back that and his conclusions were the same as mine.
comments.author: @RegularNobody

comments.text: @ 3080 was forced into 102, a severely cut down 102, because there was no other place for it given what 3070 turned out to be. 3070Ti on full 104 could easily have been called 3080, and 3070 could have been weaker because of that. Why did they try to call full ada104 4080-12? Because full 104 was x80 for a long time. And 102 is x80ti and titans territory, not x80, that's why 103 was created.
comments.author: @gariknevskoy8239

comments.text:
@gariknevskoy8239 you are correct. The X080 were on the 104 dies. I was thinking of the x080ti cards.
Thing is, all my comparisons were to the full 102 dies, so the point still stands. And the point is: anything that's not the 102 die is getting more and more cut down in favor of selling less of the die and fallbacks as features. I believe they are doing this to save the actually good silicon to the H100s, whilst also cutting down the consumer cards to force anyone who wants to do any AI related workloads to not use the consumer cards, but the more expensive enterprise stuff.
comments.author: @RegularNobody

comments.text: @RegularNobody The size of 202 is limited only by Nvidia's imagination. The big turing was only one and a half times bigger than 104. The big ampere is already almost 2 times bigger than 104. And the big ada is already almost twice as big as the much bigger and more expensive 103, and 104 was just smoking on the sidelines. Now the big ada refresh  is already more than twice as big as 203. That's why it's incorrect to count percentages if you take 202 as a starting point. As I said, you need to look at the full 103/203 and only then see what's behind it.
comments.author: @gariknevskoy8239

comments.text:
@gariknevskoy8239 I know all of this, and that logic makes no sense. In fact, it only serves to prove that everything below the 102 die is being consistently downgraded. If we are to compare specifications, we have to compare to full sized chip, which is the 102 die.
Besides, I didn't start calculating percentages that way, literally everyone has done it since forever; and, again, Steve made the exact same comparison in a video a while back, I think when the 40 series came out. And again: Historically it was consistent too: 
70 class -> mid range -> around 50% of the 102 die.
60 class -> entry level -> around 30%, sometimes even into the 40s (RTX 2060 for instance, 46% if I remember correctly)
The new 70 class is firmly below what a 60 class should be, meaning: it's a 50 class card.
Worse yet: if we rake the 5090 benchmarks into consideration and assume it applies to every card, this new architecture's performance appears to increase linearly with the the number of extra CUDA cores (i.e.: ~30% extra cores equals ~30% more performance). Not only are they selling less for more, the uplift is also terrible.
comments.author: @RegularNobody

comments.text:
With the latest Cyberpunk update, the DLSS version has been upgraded to 310.1.0.0 (nvngx_dlss.dll). By copying this DLL file into the folder where any DLSS-supported games executable file is located, we might be able to use the latest DLSS version across all games. However, the DLSS Swapper program hasnt received an update yet.

In Cyberpunk 2077, we can now switch the DLSS model from the old CNN-based method to the new Transformer model. If this model switch is necessary, developers should consider adding this option to all DLSS-supported games in the future.

On another note, the ghosting issue (trailing effects on moving objects) has been significantly reduced, which is great news. As an RTX 4080 user, the best part of the RTX 5000 series is that well also benefit from DLSS 4. For those using RTX 3000 cards, keep an eye on updatesthere are rumors that NVIDIA might bring Frame Generation to the RTX 3000 series as well.

doing a review of the 5090 and not including frame gen performance is a bit dishonest. the online discourse around frame gen is so out of touch and is just a bunch of loud neckbeard gamers giving their elitist takes. for competitive fps, fine dont include frame gen performance because latency is king in these games. but those kind of games are not graphically demanding anyways so you're just going to be cpu limited. 
the kind of games that can actually push the 5090's raw performance are those story based games where input lag isnt important and most people wouldnt really be able to notice the visual artefacts they are so minor. 
For every graphically demanding game, dlss4 turned on is indeed a good enough apples to apples comparison. your audience leans neck beard gamer more interested in pitchfork narratives than the actual demographic of gamers.

comments.text: Hearing Steve mention "CPU limitations" on the Ryzen 9800X3D is mind-boggling, yet the reasons are clear. Beyond poor optimization by game developers, Moore's Law is becoming increasingly irrelevant as even the fastest CPUs, like the Ryzen 9800X3D, struggle to meet the performance demands of the RTX 5090, creating bottlenecks. Major semiconductor manufacturers like TSMC and Intel must shift their R&D efforts toward next-generation materials, such as graphene or carbon nanotubes, which offer vastly superior electrical properties over silicon. Adopting these materials could eliminate the reliance on technologies like DLSS 4 Frame Generation and its "fake frames," enabling performance to stem from raw computational power and rasterization rather than compensating for poor optimization with artificial solutions.

comments.text: Which is a good thing... in theory. However it will never replace the actual frames. But it is something I've always wanted in a game like GTA for example. Where the game's physics is locked to 30 FPS, and GTA 4 is locked at 60 FPS. So something like 16x frames in between those frames would help immensely with motion clarity. And they game wasn't very responsive to begin with, so you wouldn't lose much. But most of the other games, especially online FPS, I would only prefer the raw frames.
comments.author: @korana6308

comments.text: @korana6308 what motion clarity if you generate artifacts?
comments.author: @mlodin84

comments.text: @mlodin84 presuming they get artifacting under control. Though I guess I was more speaking in terms of motion clarity, as I could noticably tell junkiness of the 30 fps compare to 120 and 200 and higher fps. Game felt like butter, but the physics breaks, cars can't even drive. Because the game physics is locked to 30 fps.
comments.author: @korana6308

comments.text:
@korana6308so it has the same problem as the Codemasters F1 series, that they haven't decoupled the game ligic and physics simulation from the frametate. (Worse for Codemasters F1 as that is a 2024 game, while GTA 4 is considerably older.)

Pretty much any modern sim especially racing sims runs the physics, gamelogic, physics and FFB decoupled from the framerate.
In ACC it runs at 400hz for example, so that you can run it any fraemrate you want, without issues like the Codemasters F1 series has.*

More devs should decouple gamelogic, physics and even AI from frametates.


* The issues are on both ends of the spectrum, namely that at low framerates like 60 fps or below** bumps or kerbs can be less severe, because at the speeds of an F1 car, it might pass over the highest part between two frames.
But traction is better at higher fps than at low fps, due to more data pounts.

**Yeah, yeah, before the 60 fps crowd tries to string me up, 60fps is considered a low framerate in simracing. One that it shouldn't sink below.
Like shooters or combat flight sims, sim racing demands split second decisions and reactions and is therefore very latency dependant.
144hz monitors are ok, 160 and 165hz are better, 180 is really good, 240 is  great, 360 is awesome, 480 really awesome and 560 god-like. And E-Sports or highly competitive players will drop settings to improve the framerate.
comments.author: @LupusAries

comments.author: @PSYCHOV3N0M

comments.text: If the experience is good, then it's good it doesn't matter how you get  there
comments.author: @xaviermitchell578

comments.text:
@joshuapatrick501because the generated frames don't improve latency, they don't hurt it, but one of the key reasons for a higher framerate is how quickly you can react to what is happening, with MFG you'll be reacting to an event as you think you're seeing it, but the internal game logic won't respond until at least the next real frame, instead of the time between those frames like you expected it to.

It sounds like a minor detail, but it genuinely isn't, and the way it's being marketed misleads customers, who think they're getting the felt perf of say 120fps, but in reality they're getting the felt perf of 30fps.

There's also more than a few people who will feel as though the mouse is wandering in games with MFG enabled, because they're moving the mouse in response to the visual feedback, but the cursor in reality is moving differently, this disconnect is extremely unpleasant if it is present in MFG. To be clear I don't know if it is, and I'd wager it probably isn't, but if it is, that's a problem.

Sure actual latency is no worse than without MFG, but there's a lot more to it than just "higher numbers better, so why is everyone mad?"
comments.author: @PaulTheFox1988

comments.text:
@joshuapatrick501 It might not add a lot of latency (how much will vary depending on the baseline framerate) but it certainly doesn't lower it like real frames do.

The main issue with framegen is that if you can't already achieve at least 60 fps without it (preferably higher) than using it feels awful. So when you need it the most it doesn't help. That's why most people don't consider it real performance just a motion smoother.

comments.text:
As a 4090 owner that isn't planning to get a 5090, I still think 4k RT should have been tested. I get why they didnt and I generally like the HUB reviews, but not testing 4k seems a little sus to me.

The reason you'd get a 4090 or 5090 is to basically play maxing out or nearly maxing out. And for those with features like path tracing or ray tracing implementations where it's actually significant, you're not playing those games expecting 180+ fps, and you're sure as hell not getting a 5090 to play in 1440P. 

Besides, even 4090 does pretty well in good ray tracing implemented games in native already, like the Metro Exodus enhanced. Even if the frame rates are at "console" performance (which it isn't most of the time, there are many titles where you're reaching 90+ fps native), you're still able to do that with MUCH higher image quality. As for the competitive argument, past 240 fps is diminishing return for almost the entirety of players, and you'd be playing in 1080p for less latency anyway, which you dont need a 5090 for (even 4070 ti super is overkill). 

I'm happy with my 4090 and the framerate it gets, even in the most demanding AAA titles.

I will say, I agree with not putting the MFG in this test. That needs to be its own video.

comments.text:
Exactly, you need to consider to target audience for these xx90 cards. Never has a 'top of the line' halo product (in any industry) ever been about price to performance or cost effectiveness, it's always about showing off the superiority of the brand and the pricing takes advantage of the Veblen effect. They are priced like luxury goods and the price actually makes it more appealing as a luxury good. It's not meant to be accessible. That's why the price increased, that's why the stock is always going to be low.

A 'normal' consumer review of a xx90 card is like a 'normal' consumer review of a Rolls Royce - "...it's too big and heavy and expensive, and the fuel efficiency is horrendous. Skip the Phantom and just buy a Corolla instead..."

Simply claiming that games are unplayable with upscaling seems disingenuous because even the 4090 could run Alan Wake 2 at 60 fps with 4K path tracing with DLSS set to performance mode, so saying the games wouldn't be able to run at a playable frame rate is inaccurate unless you're the type of person who absolutely needs 100+ fps on all titles.

@paulwatson9644 lol what on earth are you talking about??? What compatibility issues? I've had only amd for the last decade plus and never had any compatibility problems thay weren't my fault (i.e. trying to run metro exodus enhanced on a 5700xt because I didn't realize enhanced meant ray traced).

Fsr and dlss both look like crap except for their most recent offerings on each which aren't available on most games. Dlss (before 4.0) had so many artifacts it was unwatchable. Fsr 3.0 and earlier suck. 

Unlike dlss though fsr support can be added in via a dll file by mod. So cyberpunk has fsr 3.1 you can enable by mod and it's amazing. Doubles my frame rate without the horrendous visual artifacts. 

So still a win for amd. Also amd included dp2.1 outputs on their cards so they can actually power 4k or larger screens properly. A 4090 can't even run 240hz on a g9 because they pennypinched on the dp connector....

It's a change of Architecture. The improvements on GPU performances are not going to be as before. We are getting close to limit of Transistor sizes and putting more into a die is impossible. Thinking we are going to get same jumps forever is not very smart. 

What we will get is specialized GPU performances so checking the raw performance is going to be unimpressive from now on. The specialized GPU performance will continue to increase which in this case is gaming performance using AI. There will be other GPUs for other purposes but raw performance increase would kinda stop soon.

comments.text:
My Theory:

CUDA Cores, SMs, RT cores doesn't scale linearly with performance, ex. how the RTX 4090 having 60% more cores than the 4080 is roughly 30-35% faster than the 4080. (4090 most likely limited by L2 cache and memory bandwidth)

There is a certain amount of memory bandwidth that benefits performance in most games, beyond that limit the performance doesn't seem to be impacted. Memory bandwidth sensitive games like cyberpunk 2077 sees the biggest uplifts of around 40-50% (GN tests 50% raster uplift for CP2077 over the 4090) which can take advantage of the 1.8TB/s memory bandwidth of the 5090 where as other games which sees only a mere 20-25% uplift aren't taking advantage of the bandwidth of the RTX 5090 because at a certain amount of bandwidth (lets say 1.2TB/s, anything more than this doesn't impact performance in those games)

Maybe future titles might be more memory bandwidth sensitive and we'll see an average of 40-50% uplift for the 5090.

comments.text:
Well honestly? DLSS Upscaling was only invented by Nvidia for the same reason as DSC (display stream compression) was designed for display signals. 

It's the diminishing returns. 4k starts to already be in the territory that average human can't see all the pixels, if the display isn't big enough. Then think of the future with 8k - there is no point on trying to render all that without skipping at least some stuff. We would need many times faster GPU's that we have now for the same detail, and most people couldn't see the difference. 

Same idea probably applies in frame generation when we keep getting higher refresh rate screens. The problem again here is not that we get the smoothness of 480Hz easier for some single player game, but that the base, non-upscaled framerate starts from 30 fps... All these techs are being misused for presenting it's something else. :S

In the ideal world upscaling would be perfectly lossless like DSC is, but we're not there (yet?). This stupid bullshit that a midrange gpu even needs upscaling to get playble framerates just means, we either hit the brickwall on rendering by lack of new generation skill, or everyone got super lazy in the optimization space.
comments.author: @Kankipappa

comments.text: This has changed. All the kids are used to fake frames now so upscaling went from a bad thing to OMFG we need to pay $800 for better DLSS

lol. upscaling and framegen are here to stay, all from nvidia, amd, and even intel are keep improving this kind of tech. i mean do you remember in early 00s that we're racing to 10GHz CPU right? but as the technology keep advancing, we're no longer think that 10GHz is good choice, so... the "smarter" way invented, by using multicores albeit not 10GHz. it is better. then it change again with more cache is better than keep adding the cores/threads.

so at this point, keep upgrading the rAw PoweR is not feasible at times, too inneficient, or maybe have too many drawbacks (imagine how much electricity it cost to run Path Tracing 100fps with only rAW PowEr). so nvidia, amd, intel are pushing this upscaling and framegen to change direction how to improving the experience of gaming by using "smarter" way. 

is it perfect? no. but today it is the best solution to keep up with all the graphical fidelity we had in newer games.

comments.text: @michaeladam3190  pennies???  BoE calculations: 35 per kilowatt/hr. 5 hours a day. Average use 500 Watts. About 26 and a quarter dollars a month. 10 months, because you have vacations that you're not going to use the computer and days in between when you won't be able to use it the average amount. Around $263 per year. Vs something that averages half that amount but it's only 30% less performant. In 3 years the difference between those two is around $540.  For my work, my constantly running 4090 full system, averages around 250 to 300 watts. Just from the specs, and the reality of running on AI workloads, I expect the 5090 full system to be right around that 500 watt. Some workloads use less some workloads use more, but I also only run it approximately 18 hours in a day each day. Training takes a lot of time, sifting through all that data takes a lot of time. A gamer would be lucky to do more than 5 hours so that's the numbers that I'm using. So any prosumer, not just the gamer but somebody who actually works with the card, we'll see on average European prices and average American recent electric prices a not insignificant extra amount. In my case it will be worth it, those 48 GB of memory and the significantly higher bandwidth will help my workload, even though the price of the card is about 20% too high, for my use case

comments.text: @karlos1060 Did you just call the majority of the world clueless in a poorly written paragraph? I do not think anyone is questioning whether the same node draws the same power relative to the speed and/or transistor count. People are questioning the validity of releasing a product that consumes 30% more power, costs 25% more, and delivers only ~25% more performance, regardless of the node, speed, or transistor count it uses. Power draw is relevant to some people, especially where electricity is not cheap. For me, though, it is about the precedent of supporting a product like this. Okay, so power draw does not matter, and we as consumers never draw a lineso here comes your RTX 9090 with a 2000-watt TDP, requiring an exotic chiller to cool it. Obviously, that is an exaggeration, but seriously, where do you draw the line?

And once more in about 5 years it's the ned of getting smaller. The only option left then is eighter stop innovating and leave everything status quo. Or accept that if you want more power you will pay more power.

Nvidia is starting already the alternative of using AI for extra fps. There are not many options left. You can also build like more connected gpu's at lower powerrate and maybe save a bit of power.

In the future you can forget 50% plus increase in speed with less power. So we can talk all day long about the power usage, but the fact is not even 1% of the world buys a 5090.

It's just simple laws of physics.

In principle - that is what lack of competition does. Ignore 4090... look at where 7900XTX is... also consider that next gen AMD will bet "7-tier" car similar to 5700XT back in the day... providing competition to 5070Ti tops and probably still not reaching even the performance of 4090.

On one hand - maybe Nvidia could not improve, but in other hand THEY DON'T NEED TO. The can release glorified 2 years old design tacking few extra cores at 300W and charge $2000 for it... At this point their only competitor is themselves - why bother?

Also we just need to be clear of one thing - the performance itself is good, even 4090 looks ridiculous in graphs because it isn't even close to anything . Sort of similar to how 7800X3D and 9800X3D looks compared to Intel ... just ahead by significant margin in most games. The problem here is not performance but the price. if It was $1599 GPU, it would be amazing, but again... because of lack of competition they just decided they can price it as whatever they like... so I blame AMD for this, I blame them for sucking. 

In other hand 4090 never sold at it's RRP and was always closer to $2000 in reality... so perhaps in practice 5090 will be good value (altough whom am I kidding... it will cost $2500 in reality).

comments.text: I think its hilarious how "you reviewers" say its 25% faster for 25% more money (then when you big reviewers say it, other smaller reviewers parrot it and spread it like its something good to say).  You can absolutely NOT compare the price to a 2 year old Flagship per performance.  You're moving the goal posts.  Nearly every previous gen on gen perf uplift has been ~30% (25-35% very roughly) for THE SAME MONEY.  Not 25% more.  The incoming Gen replaces the current gen in the same price bracket.  Saying "25% faster for 25% more money" ONLY makes any sense at all when you're talking "same generation".  Not across generations 2 years later.  Asinine to even make the comparison.  OR if you live in a delusional time machine.

Also the 5080 and 5090 will target the higher resolutions 4K and above just like the 4080 and 4090, or even more thats one part of the reason for "less performance on lower resolutions". This is what these cards are made for, not 1440p or lower. I am much more interested in the 5070, and well maybe only the 5060. I am playing PC games on a 27" inch screen where the space between pixels are so close that a 4K image isnt better than a 1440p. comments.text:
It still is impressive what Nvidia has done. I hear the complaints. And yes they are there! However people buying a 4090 and 5090 game on 4K mainly. 1440P also still has a slight advantage. We do seen to forget that TMSC did not introduce a smaller node as for 2 years it is on 4nm! All the other cards have had a smaller node wich always gave good improvements in power usage and clockspeed as both had a huge advantage. So from 4000 series to 5000 series it only went from 5 to 4nm. 

When 3 or 2 nm comes out a refresh of these dies can make a huge impact. This might be also the reason why AMD did not release a new flagship GPU because they already were using more watt/fps and would have had even bigger issues to get good performance/watt.

3090 to 4090 went from 8nm to 5nm. 

5 to 4 nm was only 4% more dense. So in reality TMSC did make it only a bit cheaper to produce. Look at Intel and how long it took them to get from 14nm to 10nm(they called it 7nm but is was 10nm)

So this is the real reason we see much less performance gains over this generation. And soon we will be limited to the laws of physics and the node can't get smaller. Only die stacking can be done. So this means 2 things: eigther they will use multi dies(like chiplets) and maybe downclock it a bit to save some power or the AI thing is the way to go.

People stare to blind at ohh fake frrames and no improvement while they really don't understand the concept of it. I also think Steve from HWU is at fault for not pointing it out. 
On my Dutch Tweakers channel it is at least mentioned as these facts matter a lot.

We are almost on the limit of nm shrink as the transistor because atoms are the limit of how small it can become. Materials used are typical 0.117 or 0.122 nm. But you need space to pack and guide. So somewhere at 1nm or even a it larger is the physical limit of the die shrink.  And we are on 4nm comming from 20.000 nm back in 1968. There have always been big leaps in shrinking the node. But people think companies can apply magic. Well i have news for you people. They can't!
comments.author: @karlos1060

comments.text:
@MarcABrown-tt1fp a half baked shortcut? It's better in every way compared to rasterization for lighting. You know what's a shortcut? The method that can't display reflections or light from objects that aren't on screen...

You're wrong and that's why the entire industry is adopting ray tracing, including the next gen of consoles.
comments.author: @nk-dw2hm

comments.text:
@nk-dw2hm LMAO! If you were actually in the know about raytracing (News flash YOU ARNT! You Nvidia snub). You would know that the RTX suite isn't actual ray traced rendering. It's ray traced lighting and shadows, of which 5 samples per ray at the most on traditional rasterized geometry and textures. This is why lighting and shadows using it currently are so noisy and take time to update positions.

True Ray tracing would take 1000x longer per frame to run in current RT core implementations, needing absurd amounts of samples per ray to accommodate modern polygonal scenes, let alone using rays to calculate geometry. This is no substitute for cube mapping. I'm sorry but I see no reason not to suspect most of the gaming industry have fallen for this pitfall. Threat Interactive may be abrasive, but he was right... Maybe it will take its collapse for new talent to take its place.
comments.author: @MarcABrown-tt1fp

comments.text:
@MarcABrown-tt1fp I'm avidly against Nvidia, so it's laughable that you make those assumptions just because you disagree with me. Amd Ray tracing cards are going to power the next gen consoles. Therefore rt will be required for basically all major games moving forward. 

You can be opposed to it all you want, but it's going to happen regardless. 

And I love that you don't have a response for what I pointed out so instead you just ignore it (assuming you even read my comment). 

Rasterized lighting can't display dynamic light, shadows, or reflections for objects that aren't on screen. Those objects just don't exist until they're on screen, which will always look janky when they finally appear.

Thanks for the review, Steve. It looks like I'll be skipping this generation (can't afford shit anyway).
It's clear that this card is first and foremost a product for the machine learning/AI crowd, with their emphasis on AI-dependent features.
It's pretty clear that even the form factor that they went with (especially the very impressive cooler) is a design choice that Nvidia took so that they can more easily cram a load of these into those walk-in closets of GPU clusters for AI workloads.
I just wish that Jensen would be honest about who this product is truly for, so gamers can just ignore it and move on.

I happen to agree with HUB on this one, and from the comments on Tim's video on RT from a while ago it looks like the audience agrees. Tim included games and settings with 1% Lows of 37FPS and the crowd was having none of it. 60FPS AVG with 54FPS 1% Lows is the cut-off for what can be considered a usable configuration.

But I have the numbers from Cyberpunk with Ultra/PT at 4k: It's 20FPS vs 27FPS for 4090 vs 5090. So a 35% uplift. So exactly as expected. Yet still completely unusable.

comments.text:
@andersjjensen I completely disagree with the notion to not include those data sets just because you don't consider it playable (Which I agree with).

It's just a factually useful data point, if it's underwhelming then the comparison served it's purpose. It also informs the viewer as to where we are in relative RT performance, that we're NOT rendering games at native full scene path tracing just yet....

comments.text:
@OGPatriot03 I agree in principle. But when you read the comments it's clear that people can't keep it in their heads. People by and large think "AMD can't do RT" because in the tests where the 4090 gets 27FPS the XTX tanks to 8, so "the 4090 is 338% faster in RT! That's what the graph said!"

I think it's perfectly good "additional content" or what Steve calls "for science type content". But in day-1 product reviews I think there need to be a hard floor for what can be considered acceptable performance to include in the overall verdict.

comments.text:
No No Steve is right! IT IS the 4090 TI. Let's continue watching!

OK, finished watching now. So the 5090 REALLY isn't a gaming card. It is an AI & Rendering powerhouse! If I am making money from AI/Rendering work, like Corridor Crew, I will be lining up to buy one.

And let's call frame gen as fake frames. It is what it is whether from Nvidia or AMD. Only useful for use in high FPS monitors to smooth out panning motion.

Looking forward to see the in-depth quality comparison from Tim. I saw some small channels showed screenshots and the transformer model is slightly better than CNN for fine details and nothing more. FG does have less ghosting but that's about it.

The 5090 has more AI & RT stuff cramped in so raster has taken a backseat. This is why performance improvement is 20+% and since Apple and NVidia & AMD AI server stuff have used up all of TSMC 3nm, our GPUs are all stuck on 4nm node generation.

I do agree that the 5090 will age well as more games use exclusive Pathtracing but $2000 is too much to ask for future performance which may or may not come.

I will be upgrading my 5900X to 9950X3D on either the Asus X870e Hero or the Gigabyte X870e Aorus Extreme because I need more than 64GB of DDR5 RAM, meaning I need the best RAM speed to accommodate 4 sticks of RAM running at 6000MT/s CL32.

Both boards allow me to put my current 7900XTX for older games + AI workload and buy a second dedicated GPU for future RT games. Just waiting for reviews for RTX 5080 & Radeon 9070XT. Yes, I am seriously considering the 5080.

I want to be able to play Wukong, Squadron 42 & Indiana Jones at 60fps with DLSS Q. I can't do that with the 7900XTX without huge compromises to image quality. Especially since AMD cannot confirm FSR4 is coming to Radeon 7000.

Lastly I expect these cards to cost $2500 at retail.

comments.text:
@dante19890 I don't agree with calling motion smoothing performance. Better performance means more updates to the realtime state of the game, which frame generation can't do. It just interpolates from what has already been calculated. The only reason performance and frame rate has even become synonymous to begin with is because the way to increase frame rate was to calculate more updates to the realtime games state. The moment you introduce interpolation, you decouple those terms. You're holding a frame that's ready to be sent to the display just to interpolate the previous frame/frames, introducing input lag (in other words you're trading performance for smoother motion). Jensen said the GPU can see the future, when in reality it tries to guess the past.

For it to "see the future", they'd at least have to use extrapolation (not interpolation), which would potentially reduce input lag, but introduce horrible artifacts that would probably make the game unplayable. But even that would be just guessing the future, not actually seeing it. A third way to do frame gen would be reprojection, but that's a whole different can of worms with it's own set of limitations.

comments.author: @pian-0g445

comments.text: @sinenomine4540 CPU bottleneck. You're getting close to equivalent performance at 1440p and one could easily argue that at frame rates this high, you're so far into diminishing returns that getting the extra pixels per frame will give you a bigger advantage. At 200 fps the frame time is 5ms. A 6% improvement means 0.3ms faster frame time. Even with 4 frames of engine lag you're getting a 1.2ms advanatage at 1080p on average. Just the variability in connection speed and reaction time is an order of magnitude larger than that, even if you're a super consistent high-level player. In other words that difference won't ever manifest in a measurable advantage at that point.

Thank you for the review and keep up the amazing work

comments.text:
AMD needs to send Steve a chair for the RX 9070 XT inquisition.

The 1080p case where the RTX 4090 may be slightly faster was a condition I was anticipating.  This comes from seriously overclocking my GPUs and using Furmark.  I will say that the RTX 5090 has so many cores that the RTX 5090 can't utilize them in some 1080p loads because they are so easy, and thus the card can divert the extra power limit to boosting the clocks.  Unfortunately, the RTX 5090 has a lower boost clock than the RTX 4090, and if the RTX 4090 was not fully loaded in similar benchmarks, the RTX 4090ti... I mean the RTX 5090 will be similarly limited.

Honestly, you should have had the RTX 3090 benchmarks as well just to show the generational uplift.

Overall performance, the uplift is good... for the $1600 price tag.  Either way, the RTX 5090 does perform, and it deserves that recognition.  The power consumption will be concerning with melting connectors.  I am hoping Nvidia has a better power delivery system.  The ray tracing boosts are very disappointing given a 78% uplift in VRAM bandwidth, yet I would like to see the 4K benchmarks as well as no DLSS.  But, I consider that Nvidia could be able to improve the base performance with future driver updates.

comments.text:
@NetshadeX Well I was too old with Nvidia issues, so the switch to AMD was kinda refreshing to check out, if it was worse or not.

What I like: No multimonitor PC crashes, so no need to physically unplug broken displayport cable support that nvidia still seems to have. Linus tech tips like year or two ago said that displayport is worse than hdmi in some things, but didn't realize it's just Nvidia's driver/hw issues.

No random inputlag issues in games, no matter if it's an new or old game. It's enough that I have anti-lag set on on control panel once, then just making sure freesync and vsync is used with my LG C2 OLED TV and well, no annoying difference in inputlag between many games. With RTX 2080 I would had to most of the time just uncap my fps in even very old games like DOOM (through sourceports) to have input lag useful in 120Hz without any fiddling. AMD is just carefree in that regard.

Counter point is some Nvidia games might be broken yes, like some have mentioned helldivers 2 etc. But I guess I haven't had time to play them all when middle-age is lurking. Then again Path of Exile 2 experience has been flawless, when I still have avoided the latest Win11 update that breaks Ryzen CPU's on that game. 

However I've then read so many instability issues with Nvidia cards on crashing on PoE2, and even the developer admitted all the crashes points to Nvidia's driver issue (which has been there for 10 years if you count PoE1). So while neither brand of cards are perfect, both sides have their problems. 

Nvidia to me feels like the tweakers platform these days.

comments.text:
@WayStedYou Okay, seems I am dealing with somone a little bit stupid once again. So, Radeon VII had die size of 331 mm and 6900XT had 520 mm. That means that the 6900XT had 57% bigger die than the Radeon VII. When we look at GPU frequency 6900xt had 2250Mhz boost while the VII had 1750Mhz - that means that 6900xt had almost 29% higher clocks. Relative performance based on Techpowerup puts the 6900xt 72% over the Radeon VII - so lets add up. Base performance 100% + 57% bigger die = 157% relative performance. Now 157*1,29=205% - when you add up the lower bandwidth and that some of the die space of 6900xt is occupied by RT units you get exactly what you would expect. 5090 is the same. So AMD didnt do anything special :)
5090 over 4090 has around 23% bigger die, same clocks, non restrictive memory bandwidth and so expectedly performs around 23% better than 4090 (slightly more thanks to memory)

If you don't have a 9800x3d, and you're using upscaling which "80% of RTX users use" according to Jenson, you're reducing the performance gap by introducing a greater CPU bottleneck. In a realistic scenario such as 4k DLSS Quality, the cards are running in 1440p, so you can expect to see 15-25% differences.
yes 30% is an exaggeration, but barely so. Applying the realistic scenario makes it accurate.

comments.text: @Brent_P     Not at all. The AD102 die's full SM (streaming module) count was 144. Due to yield considerations from the manufacturing process the server class A1000 Ada had 140 working SM and the 4090 had 10% less at 128 SM units. The A1000 Ada cost 4 times a 4090... you get the picture? There was simply no room for a 4090Ti. Anything with 140+ working SM units was reserved for the A1000 Ada. I expected a 4080ti Super with a AD102 die release with less than 128 SM units but those dies got put into the 4090D for China instead. Bit of a windfall for Nvidia under the circumstances.

comments.text: @3rd.world.eliteAJ  Call it what you want, I'm simply going by what TSMC calls it, N4p. I highly doubt it's actually 5nm. It's based on the same node they used for the 40 series but not the same. Nvidia had full access to use the 3nm node for the 50 series..but they opted not to use it because it offered nothing over N4p and that's very telling. They won't even be using 3nm and will jump straight to 2nm for their next GPU release. That will offer them only 10-20% headroom over what they have now. There won't ever be a big generational uplift again. Even when they move to 1.8nm or whatever they call it. Only thing we will see are small incremental jumps with a lot more power draw and increased bandwidth. It's amazing none of these companies have been able to successfully move away from monolithic dies even though they knew it wouldn't be sustainable.

comments.author: @azraelfaust487

comments.text: @azraelfaust487Yes there is. Read FPSReview's review, a site which contains a lot of the former HardOCP reviewers. Good old pro's in the field. FG seems to match native latency when it is combined with Upscaling. Upscaling, as we know, renders the game at lower resolution. Which means higher true FPS and therefore much lower latency. Then we add FG on top and suddenly the latency jumps back to the levels what it would be in all native rendering. That means there is a clear and measurable latency penalty and if we were to add FG to native image without any upscaling, the result would not be very flattering, if not almost unplayable.
comments.author: @MaaZeus

comments.text: @lilpain1997 because your cap is YOUR final framerate (real + fake).  If he caps at 60 then 60 divided by 4 is 15 (MFG 4X) or by 2 is 30 (FG 2X).  He would need to cap at 120 not 60.  Technically with FG - Reflex must be enabled and it caps for you.  Seems he is applying an ADDITIONAL frame cap that is lower than Reflex - provided he is NOT on a 60hz TV/monitor - which would cap him at 58 with Reflex.
comments.author: @cptnsx

comments.text:
@cptnsxyup. The way it renders the frames isnt the same as say lossless scaling. If you cap the frame rate there the perceived fluidity is 120 from 60 with an input latency of 60fps. 

But when using frame gen from NVIDIA in the game settings, its producing that in a different manner and like was stated there may be another limit on top of that, but it wont go from 60 to 120 if capped at 60; youll just have 60 fps.
comments.author: @imAgentR

comments.text: Finally? Nvidia was very open to say 33% uplift in rasterization without FramGen. This is nothing new.
comments.author: @pavelpikat8950

comments.text: @imAgentR WRONG.  I HAVE a 4090.  I have used FG.  For example my monitor is in 120 mode.  If I enable FG - Reflex much be enabled.  Once you do that IT WILL CAP you at 116.  Then it will render 58 REAL frames and 58 FAKE frames.  That is HOW the tech works.  I can put my monitor in 165 mode.  Reflex caps the frames at 158 and FG is 79 REAL frames and 79 FAKE frames.  Now if YOU put an additional CAP like say 60 and then enable FG - it will (with reflex) cap you to 58 and you will have 29 REAL frames and 29 FAKE. Its how the tech works and its the same as lossless scaling - THEY ALL WORK the same way.  Nvidia simply has the hardware to reduce latency better.
comments.author: @cptnsx

comments.text:
@cptnsx

If I cap a game to 60 in-game as a best case scenario, NVIDIAs frame gen will only display 60 frames to the monitor. Its internal. The benefit then is the quality. But if I cap to 60 and frame gen x2 with LS, it will present 120fps to the monitor. Why? Because it isnt in the render pipeline the same way. You trade away internal data and accuracy, but you get interpolation that isnt locked down by the cap. I get some overhead lessened.

To achieve the same result with DLSS, obviously Id have to cap at 120, but I lose some of the gpu clearance as it were for that accuracy.

Why would I use LS then, if the quality is inferior? Less overhead. 

If I run Khazan on my hardware at a 120fps cap and frame gen with DLSS it takes 70% of the gpu to do it at 130 watts. Feels great though. 

But if use LS, cap the game to 60 and then frame gen from there I get presented 120fps also, but the overhead is now down to roughly 40% of the gpu at roughly 97 watts.

Im using a game where I can easily reach a high fps to show how different the apps are at how they interpolate in terms of working at different points in or on the frames.

Not all instances is the external approach more expensive, but then the quality loss is the deciding factor.

At an external cap at 75fps x3 in LS, I can get the perception of 225fps at the cost of roughly where DLSS frame gen sits at pushing 120fps for now on the 40-series.

I could clean up how I approached the subject for sure. But ultimately what I wanted to present is that LS in some instances is cheaper because its external and lacks DLSS accuracy.

Your rebuttal helped bring clarity. My mishap was not making clear where to cap the frames to achieve the same result. Appreciated!
